title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations related to armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary has the authority to impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations involving armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary can also compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for such violations. If a license application is denied or a license is revoked or suspended, the affected party must be provided with written notice. The Secretary can impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations with armor-piercing ammunition and has the authority to deny, revoke, or suspend licenses. The affected party must receive written notice stating the grounds for the action taken. If requested, a hearing can be held to review the denial or penalty assessment. The Secretary can impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations with armor-piercing ammunition and has the authority to deny, revoke, or suspend licenses. A hearing must be promptly held at a convenient location for the aggrieved party to review the decision. If the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision after the hearing, notice of the decision must be provided to the aggrieved party, who has a 60-day period to appeal. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court for a de novo judicial review of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment. The court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties in the proceeding. The court can order the Secretary to comply with its judgment if it decides the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment was unauthorized. The Secretary must stay the effective date of any suspension, revocation, or assessment upon request pending an appeal. SEC. 3. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
